questions.question: The reward for David’s obedience in pursuing the Amalekites was a display of God’s restoration, as he recovered all:
options: the property, wives, sons, and daughters
the former glory of the Tabernacle
questions.explanation: David 'recovered everything the Amalekites had carried off, including his two wives' (1 Sam. 30:18).

questions.question: What consequence of Adam’s disobedience affected the entire created order?
options: The destruction of the sun and moon
The permanent separation of the waters
The immediate destruction of all animals
questions.explanation: God told Adam: 'Cursed is the ground because of you; through painful toil you will eat food from it all the days of your life' (Gen. 3:17).

questions.question: What physical location was Moses forbidden to enter as a consequence of his disobedience (Deut. 34:1-6)?
questions.explanation: Moses was allowed to see the land from Mount Nebo but died there, forbidden to enter the Promised Land.

questions.question: The ultimate consequence of Saul's disobedience (1 Sam. 15:23) led to the transfer of the kingship from his own house to:
options: the man after God's own heart (David)
questions.explanation: Samuel told Saul that the Lord had 'rejected you from being king,' and had 'sought out a man after his own heart' (David) (1 Sam. 15:23, 13:14).

questions.question: The three Hebrew youths' motivation for obedience (Objective i) was their conviction that the God of Israel was the only true God, who was worthy of:
questions.explanation: Their refusal to bow was an affirmation of God's supremacy and their exclusive allegiance to Him.

questions.question: The reason the Israelites made the Golden Calf (Ex. 32) was their fear and lack of faith due to the perceived delay of:
questions.explanation: Exodus 32:1: 'When the people saw that Moses delayed to come down from the mountain...'

questions.question: Moses disobeyed by striking the rock instead of speaking to it, adding the sin of taking personal credit by saying:
options: 'Shall the Lord bring forth water for you?'
'Must *we* bring forth water for you out of this rock?'
'Did you not see what God did in Egypt?'
'You must believe the word of the prophet!'
questions.explanation: Moses said, 'Listen, you rebels, must *we* bring you water out of this rock?' (Num. 20:10), blurring the line between his power and God's power.

a man after God's own heart.name: A man after God's own heart
a man after God's own heart.category: Themes from Creation to the Division of the Kingdom

questions.question: When Samuel went to anoint the next king (Objective i), he initially thought the Lord's choice was Eliab because he was:
options: the eldest and most politically astute
the most physically strong for battle
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 16:6-7: Samuel looked at Eliab and thought, 'Surely the LORD's anointed is before him.' But the LORD said, 'Do not look on his appearance or on the height of his stature... for the LORD sees not as man sees: man looks on the outward appearance, but the LORD looks on the heart.'

questions.question: What was David doing when Samuel arrived at Jesse's house to anoint him as king?
options: He was training with the army
He was serving as a guard at the city gate
He was tending the sheep in the field
He was studying the Law with the priests
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 16:11: 'There remains yet the youngest, but behold, he is keeping the sheep.' David was brought in from the pasture.

questions.question: David’s primary reason for rejecting Saul’s armor when confronting Goliath was that the armor:
options: was too heavy and cumbersome for him to move
did not belong to his tribe, Judah
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 17:39: 'David put on his sword over his armor, and he tried in vain to go, for he had not tested them. Then David said to Saul, 'I cannot go with these, for I have not tested them.' So David took them off.'

questions.question: David proclaimed to Goliath that he came against him in the name of the Lord of Hosts so that the entire assembly might know that the Lord saves by neither:
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 17:47: '...for the battle is the LORD's, and he will give you into our hand.' David emphasized that God saves 'not with sword and spear.'

questions.question: In the cave of En Gedi, David refused to harm King Saul, calling him 'the Lord's anointed,' demonstrating David's submission to the will of God by showing:
options: a fear of Saul’s powerful army
a respect for God's divine timing and chosen authority
a desire to leave the country permanently
a belief that Saul was actually innocent
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 24:6: 'The LORD forbid that I should do this thing to my lord, the LORD's anointed, to put out my hand against him, seeing he is the LORD's anointed.' This demonstrates submitting judgment and vengeance to God.

questions.question: David again submitted to God’s will (1 Sam. 26) by refusing to let Abishai kill Saul while he slept, declaring that Saul must die only by:
options: natural causes, battle, or the hand of the Lord
the judgment of the high priest
trial by the people of Israel
the vote of the military officers
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 26:10: 'As the LORD lives,' David said, 'the LORD will strike him, or his day will come to die, or he will go down into battle and perish.'

questions.question: When David was rebuked by Nathan for his sin with Bathsheba, the specific punishment pronounced upon him was the death of:
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 12:14: 'The child that is born to you shall die.' David immediately repented and fasted upon hearing this judgment.

questions.question: David’s repentance for his great sin, recorded in Psalm 51, emphasized his need for a new and pure:
questions.explanation: Psalm 51:10: 'Create in me a clean heart, O God, and renew a right spirit within me.' This reflects his deep, internal repentance.

questions.question: After Saul’s death, David’s reign began first in Hebron, where he was made king of the tribe of:
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 2:4: 'And the men of Judah came, and there they anointed David king over the house of Judah.' The rest of Israel followed later.

questions.question: After his sick child died, David stopped fasting, washed, and went to worship God. This action demonstrated his submission to God’s will by accepting:
options: the power of God's final, irreversible judgment
the possibility of another child's death
the need to leave the kingdom permanently
the forgiveness of his great sin immediately
questions.explanation: David said, 'While the child was still alive, I fasted... But now that he is dead, why should I fast? Can I bring him back again?' (2 Sam. 12:22-23). He accepted the finality of the sentence.

questions.question: Saul sought guidance from the medium (witch) of Endor because the Lord refused to answer him through prophets, dreams, or:
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 28:6: 'And when Saul inquired of the LORD, the LORD did not answer him, either by dreams, or by Urim, or by prophets.' Saul turned to forbidden means.

questions.question: The consultation with the medium of Endor resulted in the appearance of the spirit of:
questions.explanation: The medium reported seeing an old man coming up, and Saul perceived it was Samuel (1 Sam. 28:14).

questions.question: When God offered Solomon anything he desired, Solomon’s request for an understanding heart (wisdom) was motivated by his need to:
options: judge and govern God’s great people effectively
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 3:9: 'Give your servant therefore an understanding mind to govern your people, that I may discern between good and evil, for who is able to govern this your great people?'

questions.question: The famous case of Solomon's wisdom involved two women arguing over:
options: the rightful ownership of a large plot of land
the parentage of a single living child
a dispute over the Temple treasury
the inheritance of a deceased husband
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 3:16-28 describes the case of the two prostitutes, each claiming the single surviving infant, which Solomon resolved by suggesting the child be cut in half.

questions.question: Solomon’s divinely granted wisdom exceeded that of all the people of the East and the wisdom of:
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 4:30: 'Solomon's wisdom surpassed the wisdom of all the people of the East and all the wisdom of Egypt.'

questions.question: Solomon’s later, unwise policies and decisions were primarily caused by his marriage to many foreign women who:
options: built and introduced pagan gods and worship
plotted a rebellion against the kingdom
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:4: 'For when Solomon was old his wives turned away his heart after other gods, and his heart was not wholly true to the LORD his God, as was the heart of David his father.'

questions.question: Solomon’s extensive building projects (Temple, palace, Millo) were financed through heavy taxation and the use of:
options: forced labor (conscripted service) from the population
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 9:15: 'And this is the account of the forced labor that King Solomon drafted to build the house of the LORD...'

questions.question: The ten tribes of Israel rebelled against Rehoboam because he followed the advice of the young men and promised to replace his father's heavy yoke with one that was:
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 12:14: 'My father disciplined you with whips, but I will discipline you with scorpions.' This promise to increase their burdens caused the revolt.

questions.question: Whose counsel did Rehoboam reject, leading directly to the division of the kingdom?
options: The counsel of his military commanders
The counsel of the older men
The counsel of the prophet Ahijah
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 12:8: 'But he abandoned the counsel that the old men gave him and took counsel with the young men who had grown up with him.'

questions.question: During his flight from Saul, David gathered a group of men who were in distress, debt, or discontented. Where did David establish a stronghold for these men?
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 22:1: 'David departed from there and escaped to the cave of Adullam. And when his brothers and all his father's house heard of it, they went down there to him.'

questions.question: The anointing of David (1 Sam. 16:13) was marked by the immediate outpouring of the:
options: Spirit of the LORD upon him
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 16:13: 'Then Samuel took the horn of oil and anointed him in the midst of his brothers, and the Spirit of the LORD rushed upon David from that day forward.'

questions.question: David’s submission to God’s will is reflected in his prayer that the punishment for his sin would not extend to:
options: the guilt of the prophet Nathan
the life of the innocent child
questions.explanation: David fasted and prayed for the life of the child, demonstrating a deep humility and acceptance of God's authority over life and death.

questions.question: The prophet Nathan confronted David using the allegory of a rich man who stole and slaughtered the only **lamb** belonging to:
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 12:1-4 describes Nathan’s parable about a rich man (David) who took the poor man's (Uriah’s) only lamb (Bathsheba).

questions.question: To prove to Saul that he could have killed him in the cave, David showed Saul a piece of the king’s:
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 24:4: David crept up and secretly cut off a corner of Saul’s robe. This action proved his restraint.

questions.question: Saul’s reliance on the medium (1 Sam. 28) demonstrated a final, desperate act of disobedience because the Law explicitly classified all such practices as:
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 18:10-12 and 1 Samuel 28:3 indicate that seeking a medium was an 'abomination' and a wicked practice, resulting in the cutting off of the person.

questions.question: Solomon’s judgment on the two women was designed to reveal which woman possessed genuine:
questions.explanation: The true mother (maternal compassion) would rather relinquish the child than see it cut in half. Solomon's ruling revealed the heart.

questions.question: The Bible says Solomon spoke 3,000 proverbs and 1,005:
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 4:32: 'He composed three thousand proverbs, and his songs were one thousand and five.'

questions.question: The ultimate consequence of Solomon’s unwise, idolatrous policies was that God promised to tear the kingdom from his son’s hand, leaving only one tribe for the sake of:
options: the high priest and his line
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:13: 'Nevertheless, I will not tear away all the kingdom, but will give one tribe to your son, for the sake of David my servant and for the sake of Jerusalem.'

questions.question: Rehoboam's rejection of the old men’s counsel and adoption of the young men’s harsh policy was described as an act that was actually from:
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 12:15: 'So the king did not listen to the people, for it was a turn of affairs brought about by the LORD, that he might fulfill his word...'

questions.question: David won the hand of Saul’s daughter Michal by proving his worth in battle against the Philistines, offering Saul 200:
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 18:27: 'And David arose and went, along with his men, and killed two hundred of the Philistines. And David brought their foreskins, which they gave in full number to the king, that he might become the king's son-in-law.'

questions.question: When David spared Saul’s life a second time, what item did he take from the sleeping king to prove he had been near him?
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 26:11-12: David told Abishai not to strike Saul; instead, they took the spear and the jar of water from Saul’s head.

questions.question: In Psalm 51, David asked God to wash him thoroughly from his iniquity and cleanse him from his:
questions.explanation: Psalm 51:2: 'Wash me thoroughly from my iniquity, and cleanse me from my sin!'

questions.question: Samuel’s spirit delivered a final message to Saul, prophesying that Saul and his sons would be with Samuel in:
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 28:19: 'Moreover, the LORD will also give Israel along with you into the hand of the Philistines, and tomorrow you and your sons will be with me.'

questions.question: Because Solomon asked for wisdom to judge the people and not riches or long life, God gave him wisdom and also granted him:
options: military strength and a large army
a peaceful end to his reign
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 3:13: 'I give you also what you have not asked, both riches and honor, so that no king in all your days shall be comparable to you.'

questions.question: The primary cause of Solomon's spiritual downfall and unwise policies was his failure to keep God’s commandments due to the influence of:
options: his excessive taxation and forced labor
his reliance on the wisdom of Egypt
his inability to manage the Temple finances
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:3-4: 'He had 700 wives, princesses, and 300 concubines. And his wives turned away his heart...'

questions.question: The ten northern tribes that rebelled against Rehoboam took as their king:
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 12:20: 'And when all Israel heard that Jeroboam had returned, they sent and called him to the assembly and made him king over all Israel.'

questions.question: David's father, Jesse, and his family fled to Moab for safety while David was being pursued by Saul, showing David's:
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 22:3-4: David took his parents to Moab, asking the king there to let them stay until he knew what God would do for him.

questions.question: What immediate, concise statement did David make when Nathan confronted him with the parable of the lamb?
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 12:13: 'David said to Nathan, 'I have sinned against the LORD.' This was the core of his repentance.

questions.question: The Lord told Samuel to anoint David because the Lord was looking at David’s:
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 16:7: '...for the LORD sees not as man sees: man looks on the outward appearance, but the LORD looks on the heart.'

questions.question: Saul's reliance on the medium for guidance was considered a greater sin than his previous disobedience because it involved seeking advice from:
options: a practice condemned under the covenant law
a man he had previously arrested
questions.explanation: Saul's own previous reform efforts had driven out the mediums and spiritists, making his action a direct, desperate violation of the Law.

questions.question: King Hiram of Tyre agreed to send cedar and cypress logs for the Temple because he had heard of Solomon's:
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 5:7: 'When Hiram heard the words of Solomon, he rejoiced greatly and said, 'Blessed be the LORD this day, who has given to David a wise son to be over this great people.''

questions.question: Solomon's idolatry and disobedience raised up two adversaries against him: Hadad the Edomite and Rezon, the son of Eliada, from:
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:23: 'God also raised up as an adversary to him, Rezon the son of Eliada, who had fled from his lord Hadadezer king of Zobah.' (Syria/Aram).

questions.question: The older counselors advised Rehoboam to lighten the load on the people and speak to them with:
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 12:7: 'If you will be a servant to this people today and serve them, and speak good words to them when you answer them, then they will be your servants forever.'

questions.question: After David confessed his sin, Nathan immediately told him that the Lord had done what regarding his sin?
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 12:13: 'Nathan said to David, 'The LORD also has put away your sin; you shall not die.'

questions.question: David's close friendship with Saul's son, Jonathan, demonstrated that Jonathan placed loyalty to David above his own:
questions.explanation: Jonathan recognized David as the next king and willingly relinquished his right to the throne to support David.

questions.question: David spared Saul’s life a second time to ensure that his own ascent to the throne was entirely dependent upon:
questions.explanation: David’s commitment was to let the LORD 'strike him' (Saul) or wait for him to die naturally, ensuring his hands were clean of the anointed king's blood.

questions.question: The depth of Solomon’s wisdom was evident in his deep knowledge of:
options: all forms of plant and animal life
the history of the surrounding nations
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 4:33: 'He spoke of trees, from the cedar that is in Lebanon to the hyssop that grows out of the wall. He spoke also of animals, and of birds, and of creeping things, and of fish.'

questions.question: A major economic and political unwise policy of Solomon was his extensive trade relationship with Egypt, which primarily involved:
options: the export of wheat and olive oil
the exchange of gold for silver
the import and sale of horses and chariots
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 10:28-29 detail Solomon's trade monopoly in importing horses and chariots from Egypt, contrary to Deuteronomic law for a king.

questions.question: The Northern Kingdom’s formal declaration of rebellion against the house of David (1 Kings 12:16) was summarized by the phrase, 'What portion have we in David? We have no inheritance in the son of Jesse! To your tents, O:
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 12:16: '...What portion have we in David? We have no inheritance in the son of Jesse! To your tents, O Israel!'

questions.question: Psalm 130, 'Out of the depths I cry to you, O LORD,' reflects David’s deep repentance and his final reliance on God’s power to provide:
options: a permanent place in the Temple
questions.explanation: Psalm 130:4: 'But with you there is forgiveness, that you may be feared.' Psalm 130:7: '...for with the LORD there is steadfast love, and with him is plentiful redemption.'

decision making.name: Decision Making
decision making.category: Themes from Creation to the Division of the Kingdom

questions.question: Saul chose to rely on a medium (1 Sam. 28) for guidance because the LORD refused to answer him through all the approved means, including the prophets, dreams, and:
options: the counsel of his military general
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 28:6 states the LORD did not answer Saul 'either by dreams, or by Urim, or by prophets.' When God was silent, Saul resorted to forbidden means.

questions.topic_focus: Solomon's Wisdom Source (I Kings 3:3-15, Objective i)
questions.question: The ultimate source of Solomon’s wisdom (Objective i) was:
options: his excellent formal education in Egypt
his inheritance from his father, David
a direct gift from God in response to his humble request
the vast number of books he read
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 3:12: 'behold, I now do according to your word; indeed I have given you a wise and discerning heart.' God granted it as a gift.

questions.topic_focus: Solomon's Wise Decision (I Kings 3:16-28, Objective iii)
questions.question: Solomon’s wise decision regarding the two women and the single child (Objective iii) was to order the living child to be cut in half in order to:
options: punish both women for their quarrel
ensure a fair distribution of the property
reveal the true mother through her compassion
teach the court attendants a lesson about justice
questions.explanation: The true mother's instinct was to save the child, while the false claimant agreed to the division. The ruling revealed the truth of their hearts.

questions.topic_focus: Solomon's Unwise Decisions (I Kings 11:1-8, Objective iii)
questions.question: Solomon’s most damaging unwise decision (Objective iii) was his choice to marry many foreign women who:
options: forced him to abandon his administrative duties
turned his heart to worship other gods
wasted the nation’s wealth on lavish clothing
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:4: 'For when Solomon was old his wives turned away his heart after other gods, and his heart was not wholly true to the LORD his God...'

questions.question: Rehoboam made the unwise decision (Objective iii) to reject the advice of the older counselors who advised him to:
options: lighten the people's labor and speak kindly
move the capital city to the north
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 12:7: The elders advised him to 'be a servant to this people... and speak good words to them,' but he chose the harsh counsel of the young men.

questions.question: A key difference in the decision-making of Saul and Solomon (Objective ii) is that Saul relied on forbidden practices out of desperation, while Solomon's key decisions were initially based on:
questions.explanation: Saul used the medium (forbidden/desperate). Solomon used prayer and the divinely granted wisdom (authorized/humble).

questions.question: The major consequence of Solomon’s unwise, idolatrous decisions (Objective iv) was God’s promise to tear away the kingdom from his line, leaving only the tribe of Judah for the sake of:
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:13: 'Nevertheless, I will not tear away all the kingdom, but will give one tribe to your son, for the sake of David my servant and for the sake of Jerusalem which I have chosen.'

questions.question: The immediate consequence of Rehoboam’s unwise policy (Objective iv) was the division of the united kingdom into two separate entities: Judah and:
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 12:19-20 describes how Israel rebelled against the house of David and chose Jeroboam as king over the northern tribes (Israel).

questions.question: Solomon’s wisdom (Objective i) was not merely judicial; it also encompassed vast knowledge of nature, as demonstrated by his speaking of animals, birds, fish, and all types of:
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 4:33: 'He spoke of trees, from the cedar that is in Lebanon to the hyssop that grows out of the wall.'

questions.question: The decision to consult the medium ultimately confirmed Saul’s impending doom because the spirit of Samuel told him that the Lord would hand the kingdom over to:
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 28:17: 'The LORD has torn the kingdom out of your hand and given it to your neighbor, David.'

questions.question: Solomon's wise decision to build the Temple was a faithful continuation of the vision of:
questions.explanation: Solomon fulfilled David's desire and prepared for the Temple's construction (1 Kings 5:5).

questions.question: Rehoboam rejected the counsel of the older men because he felt their advice was too:
questions.explanation: The young men urged him to show strength and dominance, finding the old men's advice of serving the people to be weak.

questions.question: The difference between Saul’s and Solomon’s final decision-making processes (Objective ii) is that Solomon fell due to **internal** compromise (idolatry), while Saul fell due to **external** desperation and:
questions.explanation: Saul was driven by fear and spiritual desperation to use forbidden methods (medium). Solomon was led astray by lust and foreign wives.

questions.question: One immediate consequence (Objective iv) of Solomon’s foreign wives and worship was that God raised up adversaries, including Hadad the Edomite and Rezon of:
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:23: God raised up Rezon, who became king over Aram (Syria).

questions.question: The specific declaration made by the ten tribes of Israel when they rebelled against Rehoboam (Objective iv) was, 'What portion have we in David? We have no inheritance in the son of Jesse! To your tents, O...'
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 12:16 records the cry of the rebellious northern tribes: '...To your tents, O Israel!'

questions.topic_focus: Solomon's Wisdom Source (I Kings 3:3-15, Objective i)
questions.question: God’s decision to grant Solomon wisdom was because Solomon’s request was motivated by a desire for:
options: a long life and the death of his enemies
the ability to serve and judge God’s people well
the immediate building of the Temple
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 3:9: 'Give your servant therefore an understanding mind to govern your people...'

questions.question: Saul’s decision to consult the medium was particularly grievous because he himself had previously done what regarding mediums and spiritists?
options: Appointed them as his personal advisors
Promoted them to the highest offices
Expelled them from the land of Israel
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 28:3: 'Saul had removed the mediums and the necromancers from the land.' His own action condemned his later decision.

questions.topic_focus: Solomon's Wise Decision (I Kings 3:16-28, Objective iii)
questions.question: The entire nation of Israel realized the presence of God's wisdom in Solomon because they heard of his judgment and saw that he had:
options: a large amount of personal gold
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 3:28: 'And all Israel heard of the judgment that the king had rendered, and they stood in awe of the king, because they perceived that the wisdom of God was in him to do justice.'

questions.topic_focus: Solomon's Unwise Decisions (I Kings 9:15-23, Objective iv)
questions.question: A major consequence of Solomon's unwise building policies (Objective iv) was the widespread use of forced labor, resulting in national:
questions.explanation: Solomon's heavy taxation and compulsory labor led to the national resentment that fueled the later rebellion under Rehoboam.

questions.question: The decisive moment in Rehoboam's decision (Objective iii) was when he chose to act on the arrogant advice of the young men who had:
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 12:8: '...and took counsel with the young men who had grown up with him and stood before him.'

questions.question: Saul's decision-making (Objective ii) was characterized by **fear and superstition**, while Solomon's decision-making during his prime was characterized by:
questions.explanation: Solomon asked for wisdom out of humility to serve God's people, the opposite of Saul's fearful desperation.

questions.question: The ultimate consequence of Solomon’s unwise decisions (Objective iv) regarding his foreign wives and idols was that God tore away ten tribes, fulfilling the prophecy of Ahijah, the prophet of:
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:29-31: The prophet Ahijah of Shiloh prophesied the division of the kingdom by tearing a new cloak into twelve pieces.

questions.question: Rehoboam's unwise decision led to the loss of the Northern Kingdom, but he retained control over the Kingdom of Judah and the tribe of:
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 12:21: The tribes of Judah and Benjamin remained loyal to Rehoboam and the house of David.

questions.topic_focus: Solomon's Wisdom Source (I Kings 4:29-34, Objective i)
questions.question: The source of Solomon's exceptional wisdom (Objective i) was not limited to Israel, as it surpassed the wisdom of all the people of the East and the wisdom of:
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 4:30: 'Solomon's wisdom surpassed the wisdom of all the people of the East and all the wisdom of Egypt.'

questions.question: The spirit of Samuel prophesied to Saul that the Philistines would defeat Israel and that Saul and his sons would:
options: live to see a new king
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 28:19: '...and tomorrow you and your sons will be with me,' referring to their death.

questions.topic_focus: Solomon's Wise Decision (I Kings 5:1-12, Objective iii)
questions.question: Solomon’s wise decision to form an alliance with Hiram, King of Tyre (Objective iii), was primarily for the purpose of obtaining:
options: skilled craftsmen and timber for the Temple
gold and silver from their treasury
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 5:6: Solomon asked Hiram to 'cut cedar logs for me' and send craftsmen, as the Sidonians were excellent timber workers.

questions.topic_focus: Solomon's Unwise Decisions (I Kings 11:1-8, Objective iii)
questions.question: As a result of his foreign wives' influence, Solomon’s unwise decisions (Objective iii) included building high places for the worship of detestable gods like Chemosh (of Moab) and:
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:7: 'Then Solomon built a high place for Chemosh the detestable god of Moab, and for Molech the detestable god of the sons of Ammon, on the mountain which is east of Jerusalem.'

questions.question: The issue that drove the Northern Tribes to Rehoboam seeking a decision (Objective iii) was the heavy burden of his father Solomon's:
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 12:4: 'Your father made our yoke heavy. Now therefore lighten the hard service of your father and his heavy yoke upon us, and we will serve you.'

questions.question: The decision-making process of both Saul (seeking a medium) and the later Solomon (consulting foreign wives) (Objective ii) failed because they both neglected the primary authority of:
options: the Law and the word of the LORD
questions.explanation: The Law forbids mediums and idolatry. Both leaders eventually rejected God's revealed instruction in favor of ungodly counsel.

questions.question: The consequence (Objective iv) of Solomon’s idol worship was not just political division, but the spiritual decay of his heart which was no longer fully devoted to God, resulting in:
options: the loss of his military power
a failure to keep the covenant law
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:11: 'Since this has been done by you, and you have not kept My covenant and My statutes... I will surely tear the kingdom from you.'

questions.question: The historical consequence of Rehoboam’s decision (Objective iv) was the permanent split of the twelve tribes, establishing the two kingdoms known as:
questions.explanation: The division established the Southern Kingdom of Judah (Judah and Benjamin) and the Northern Kingdom of Israel (the other ten tribes).

questions.topic_focus: Solomon's Wisdom Source (I Kings 3:3-15, Objective i)
questions.question: Solomon received his wisdom at what location, where he offered a thousand burnt offerings?
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 3:4-5: 'The king went to Gibeon to sacrifice there, for that was the great high place... At Gibeon the LORD appeared to Solomon in a dream by night.'

questions.question: Saul's decision to seek the medium was analyzed by the spirit of Samuel as an ultimate act of disobedience because Saul failed to:
options: obey the voice of the LORD
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 28:18: 'Because you did not obey the voice of the LORD and did not execute His fierce wrath on Amalek, therefore the LORD has done this thing to you this day.'

questions.topic_focus: Solomon's Wise Decision (I Kings 8:1-53, Objective iii)
questions.question: During the dedication of the Temple, Solomon’s decision (Objective iii) was to lead the people in an elaborate ceremony, including:
options: seven days of sacrifice and feast
the anointing of a new high priest
the reading of the entire Law of Moses
a public address to the foreign nations
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 8:65: Solomon held a feast that lasted fourteen days (seven for the Temple, seven for the King).

questions.topic_focus: Solomon's Unwise Decisions (I Kings 9:15-23, Objective iii)
questions.question: In his later decisions (Objective iii), Solomon treated the remaining **Canaanites** in the land by making them:
options: rulers over the tribes of Israel
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 9:20-21: 'All the people who were left of the Amorites, the Hittites, the Perizzites, the Hivites and the Jebusites... Solomon subjected to forced labor.'

questions.question: Rehoboam's final, defiant decision (Objective iii) was to send Adoram, who was in charge of the forced labor, to the Northern Tribes. What happened to Adoram?
options: He was welcomed warmly by Jeroboam
He was sent back to Jerusalem with a message
He was immediately stoned to death by the people
He was made a military commander
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 12:18: 'Then King Rehoboam sent Adoram, who was in charge of the forced labor, and all Israel stoned him to death with stones.'

questions.question: When analyzing their decision-making (Objective ii), both Saul and Solomon eventually replaced God's established counsel with their own:
questions.explanation: Saul acted on his fear (self-will), and Solomon acted on his lust and foreign wives' demands (self-will), both rejecting God's word.

questions.question: The prophecy of Ahijah regarding the split kingdom (Objective iv) was symbolized by the tearing of a new garment into how many pieces?
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:30: Ahijah 'tore it into twelve pieces,' symbolizing the twelve tribes.

questions.question: The division of the kingdom, a consequence of Rehoboam’s folly (Objective iv), directly contradicted God’s promise of an eternal dynasty to the house of:
questions.explanation: The split severely limited the scope of the Davidic dynasty, confining it to Judah, yet preserving the lineage promised to David.

questions.topic_focus: Solomon's Wisdom Source (I Kings 3:3-15, Objective i)
questions.question: After God granted Solomon wisdom, He also promised him long life on the condition that Solomon would:
options: walk in God’s ways and keep His statutes
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 3:14: 'And if you will walk in my ways, keeping my statutes and my commandments, as your father David walked, then I will lengthen your days.'

questions.question: The final result of Saul’s decision (Objective iii) to consult the medium was not victory or peace, but rather:
options: despair and fear before the battle
a prophecy of a long reign
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 28:20: 'Then Saul immediately fell full length upon the ground and was greatly afraid because of the words of Samuel.'

questions.topic_focus: Solomon's Wise Decision (I Kings 8:1-53, Objective iii)
questions.question: What was placed inside the Ark of the Covenant just before it was brought into the completed Temple during Solomon's dedication (Objective iii)?
options: A portion of manna and Aaron’s rod
Only the two tablets of stone
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 8:9: 'There was nothing in the ark except the two tablets of stone which Moses put there at Horeb...'

questions.topic_focus: Solomon's Unwise Decisions (I Kings 11:1-40, Objective iii)
questions.question: One of the consequences of Solomon’s unwise, idolatrous decisions (Objective iii) was his failure to:
options: keep the high places he built for God
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:11: 'I will surely tear the kingdom from you... because you have not kept My covenant and My statutes.'

questions.question: The young men advised Rehoboam to tell the people that his little finger would be thicker than his father’s:
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 12:10: 'My father made your yoke heavy, but I will add to your yoke; my father disciplined you with whips, but I will discipline you with scorpions.'

questions.question: Saul's decision to consult the medium (Objective ii) was primarily influenced by the absence of **divine counsel**, whereas Solomon’s fall was due to the presence of:
questions.explanation: Solomon allowed the direct influence of his pagan wives and their idols to corrupt his heart.

questions.question: A negative social consequence of Solomon’s policies (Objective iv) was that the Israelites had to sustain his large number of officials and servants through heavy:
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 4:7, 22-23 details the twelve officials responsible for providing food for the king and his household, which necessitated heavy taxation from the people.

questions.question: The northern tribes' rebellion against Rehoboam (Objective iv) was a demonstration of the people's strong preference for a king who would:
options: show political wisdom and lighten their burdens
establish a new temple of worship
questions.explanation: The people initially sought a lighter yoke and a kind, wise response, but Rehoboam’s arrogance alienated them permanently.

questions.topic_focus: Solomon's Wisdom Source (I Kings 4:29-34, Objective i)
questions.question: The wisdom granted to Solomon (Objective i) was so vast that people from all parts of the earth came to hear his wisdom, sent by their:
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 4:34: 'And people came from all the nations to hear the wisdom of Solomon, and from all the kings of the earth who had heard of his wisdom.'

questions.question: Saul’s decision to consult the medium (Objective iii) revealed his final rejection of God’s authority by refusing to wait for God’s instruction and resorting to:
questions.explanation: Consulting a medium was considered a form of idolatrous ritual, which Saul had himself previously banned.

questions.topic_focus: Solomon's Unwise Decisions (I Kings 11:1-40, Objective iv)
questions.question: God’s consequence for Solomon’s failure (Objective iv) was partially restrained (only one tribe left) due to His covenant love and promise to:
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:12: 'Nevertheless, I will not do it in your days, for the sake of your father David.'
